SENT.plain: The effect of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) on the adrenergic innervation of cat cerebral arteries was analyzed
Intracisternal injections of autologous blood reduced the noradrenaline content from the perivascular nerves
Dopamine beta-hydroxylase and the uptake of 3H-noradrenaline were also decreased
These changes returned to normal in a period of 2 to 3 weeks after the SAH
Superior cervical ganglionectomy and intracisternal injections of 6-hydroxydopamine also reduced these three parameters
It is suggested that SAH induces a transient adrenergic denervation of the cerebral arteries that might be involved in the production of the chronic cerebral vasospasm
